Yes, convenience and cost are significant factors that influence why many farmers still use synthetic fertilizers. Synthetic fertilizers are easily accessible and relatively cheap compared to organic fertilizers. They are also more convenient to transport, store and apply than organic fertilizers, which can be bulky and require specialized equipment for application.

Moreover, synthetic fertilizers tend to produce higher crop yields in the short term, whereas organic farming practices may take longer to accumulate nutrients and can be less predictable in terms of yield. This makes it challenging for farmers who operate on tight profit margins to switch to organic practices.

Some farmers may also lack knowledge about how to implement organic practices, and the transition to organic farming requires significant investment in training, new equipment, and often a change in cropping systems, which can be daunting and costly.

Despite these challenges, many farmers are gradually adopting organic farming practices in response to consumers' growing demand for sustainably produced food, as well as the increasing recognition of the long-term benefits of organic farming for soil health, biodiversity, and climate resilience.
